resources.string: Tips for getting around Puen city
Show some tips and tricks related to Traveling aroun Pune city.

According to Lonely Planet from 2002, there are 2.8 million people in Pune. I would assume it is much more now. 

Change money as soon as you can or get it from an ATM (there are plenty, not all accept all cards). 

Most places do not take dollars, at least not at a reasonable rate. 

Get the business card or your hotel and keep it on you at all times, handy for finding your way back. 

It is usually easy to find a helpful guy speaking English. However, if you do not, it is important to pronounce names (e.g. of places) in local accent, as people will not understand you otherwise. Try to mimic the accent of locals when you do that.

Around Koregon park - there is a western atmosphere here. Many tourists come here for the Oshu ashram.

Around MG Road, area know as Pune Camp. There are many local places here, so this is my favorite place. I stayed at the Sagar Plaza Hotel which has a perfect location. Highly recommended.

Try to avoid hotels with are in the western part of the city if you are working in Magarpatta. There is also not much to do there.

You DO NOT want to rent a car and drive on your own. You will understand once you will see how people drive.

No taxis in Pune. There are many transport companies and you can arrange a car with a driver, but you cannot just hail a cab. Instead you have rickshaws.

Rickshaws - They are a great way to travel.

Looking for an English speaking rickshaw driver? Call Aiub Khan at 988-140-8465, at least an hour in advance.

After-noons to early evenings means heavy congestions in Pune. Late mornings can be hectic as well. In fact, other than late night it is congested.

Snacks - small meals. Usually comprised of south Indian delicacies. Do not miss the Masala Dosa which is a lentil pancake with little potato stuffing.

Thali - a preset meal where you get a number of dishes, bread and rice. It is all you can eat - waiters will keep refilling your place. However, you are eating what everybody else are eating, so you cannot ask to make it less spicy.

Sizzlers - found in specific places. You get a sizzling pan with some stir-fried vegetables and meat. It is not really Indian food.

Chinese food is very popular. Most of it is very far from the source and tastes Indian.

There are many types of Indian cuisines - northern, southern, Punjabi, Gujarati, Hyderabadi, Kashmiri, etc. Each has different flavors and dishes. Experiment and find your favorite.
